page.title: 15ECOLOGY IN STOCKSBRIDGE
page.content: THE VEGETATION RANGES FROM HIGH HEATHER MOORLAND WITH BILBERRY AND MOUNTAIN ASH, DOTTED WITH SMALL MARSHY AREAS WITH SEDGES AND COTTON GRASS CUT BY RIVERS. THIS AREA IS WINDSWEPT, OPEN AND HARSH. THIS LEADS TO ROUGH PASTURE LAND WITH POOR GRASSES, BRACKEN AND GORSE, GRAZED BY SHEEP AND ENCLOSED BY STONE WALLS. THERE IS LOWER FLATTER LAND WITH CULTIVATED GRASSES FOR CATTLE AS WELL AS USED FOR GROWING CEREALS AND POTATOES. THE RIVER 'LITTLE DON' IS POLLUTED HEAVILY AS IT PASSES THE STEEL WORKS WHILE NEARBY 'EWDEN BECK' IS A CLEAR, COLD, ACID MOORLAND STREAM WITH A STEEP SIDED DENSELY DECIDUOUS WOODED VALLEY. THE UNDERLYING ROCKS ARE ACIDIC, SANDSTONE AND MILLSTONE GRIT. THE SOIL IN GENERAL IS SHALLOW AND RATHER POOR.THE AIR IS MINIMALLY POLLUTED BY THE STEEL WORKS.
